column1: The king's daughter was now mournful
column3: blind-sorrowful for her married man; she was always with her eye on the loch. An old soothsayer met her
column4: and she told how it had befallen her married mate. Then he told her the thing to do to save her mate
column5: and that she did. She took her harp to the sea-shore
column6: and sat and played; and the sea-maiden came up to listen
column7: for sea-maidens are fonder of music than all other creatures. But when the wife saw the sea-maiden she stopped. The sea-maiden said
column10: not till I see my man again." So the sea-maiden put up his head out of the loch. Then the princess played again
column11: and stopped till the sea-maiden put him up to the waist. Then the princess played and stopped again
column12: and this time the sea-maiden put him all out of the loch
column13: and he called on the falcon and became one
column14: and flew on shore. But the sea-maiden took the princess
